content: The "Stephanie Tubbs Jones Gift of Life Medal Act of 2008" establishes eligibility requirements for a medal for organ donors or their families. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will oversee the application process for the medal. The "Stephanie Tubbs Jones Gift of Life Medal Act of 2008" establishes eligibility criteria for organ donor medals. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will verify eligibility and present medals to qualifying individuals or families through organ procurement organizations. Only one medal can be awarded to a family, typically to the donating family member or the one who authorized the organ donation. The Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network may collect funds to offset expenditures for issuing medals under the Stephanie Tubbs Jones Gift of Life Medal Act of 2008. Funds received will be paid to the Secretary of Health and Human Services for purchasing medals and covering administrative costs. The Secretary of the Treasury will design and strike the Stephanie Tubbs Jones Gift of Life Medal Act of 2008. Only 7 percent of funds received can be used for administrative and fundraising costs by the Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network. Federal funds cannot be used for purchasing medals or administrative costs related to the Act. The Stephanie Tubbs Jones Gift of Life Medals, weighing 250 grams and with a 3-inch diameter, will be designed by the Secretary of the Treasury in bronze. The design will commemorate organ donors' compassion and courage, with emblems and inscriptions. The design will be selected in consultation with various parties and reviewed by the Citizens Coin Advisory Committee. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike and deliver national medals to the Secretary of Health and Human Services in minimum-sized lots of at least 100 medals. The cost of the medals sold to the Secretary of Health and Human Services will cover designing, striking, labor, materials, dies, machinery, and overhead expenses. The Secretary of the Treasury is prohibited from making expenditures in advance of receiving funds. The Secretary of the Treasury must wait for certification of sufficient funds from the Secretary of Health and Human Services before striking or distributing any medals under the Act. However, the Treasury Secretary can start designing the medal and taking necessary actions in preparation. Medals under this Act are not considered valuable consideration for the National Organ Transplant Act. The Transplant Act defines key terms such as "organ," "organ procurement organization," and "Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network."
